Mount Kilimanjaro Mount Kilimanjaro is the highest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed Kilimanjaro from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are several paths to the top. People think that the five-kilometre Marangu path is the easiest. It takes about five days and is very popular with tourists. One of the most difficult paths is the nine-kilometre Lemosho path. This route is longer but less crowded than the other routes.

It takes about seven days. The mountain has five zones - cultivated land, cloud forest, heath and moorland, alpine desert and ice cap. Every zone is very different. This means that climbers are always challenged as they move higher.

It has three volcanic cones. One of them, called Kibo, is the highest. The mountain was formed about 750,000 years ago and was once taller than the Eiffel Tower. It was made from lava and is still active. Scientists have never measured its depth, but they say it could be as deep as 600 metres. Mount Kilimanjaro is also home to several rare animals. It is home to some species of plants that are found no-where else.

You don't have to be super-fit to climb the mountain. You do need to prepare, but you can always go back down if you have to. It is not a cheap activity, however, and you will need lots of warm clothes. People who reach the top are rewarded with an amazing view of the surroundings.

It's not just for fun. The money raised by climbers is used to support poor local people. You may be helping to feed a child

Maria Mutola In 1988 Maria Mutola was playing football as the only girl in an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won' she said. 'At first no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' The story appeared in a local newspaper and Jose Craveirinha who had encouraged other African athletes learnt about Maria. He saw potential, approached her and offered a scholarship to a sports academy in East Germany. In 1996 she was part of the national athletics team that won a silver medal at the Olympics. She went on to win two gold medals at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, becoming the only woman ever to win two gold medals in the same track event. She became a four-time Olympic silver and bronze medalist and an eight-time world champion. In a world that has often overlooked or underestimated the athletic capacity of African athletes, she was a revelation.' She retired from athletics in 2010.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every autumn the sky above the desert city of Albuquerque in the south-western United States turns into a mass of bright colours. This is the Albuquerque Balloon festival an annual nine-day event. The first festival was held in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of the local radio station.

It has since become a very popular event that attracts hot air balloonists from around the world. During the festival a large number of colourful hot air balloons take to the sky with thousands of people below looking up. People come to this festival to watch the many hot air balloons that fill the sky. There are also many other activities for them to enjoy. The Albuquerque balloon festival is not only fun, but it helps to raise money for local charities as well.

In addition to the launching of hot air balloons, other activities such as craft fairs, live music performances, and food vendors provide a festive atmosphere. The festival is a massive affair that lasts for nine days and has grown from just over 30 hot air balloons in 1972 to over 500 today.

Over the years it has become a popular tourist attraction, especially for families and has drawn tens of thousands of visitors each year. In addition, ballooning competitions and balloon glow shows at nighttime are held. In the glow shows, the balloons are inflated and anchored, then their burners are ignited to illuminate the balloon envelopes, a very impressive sight.

The Albuquerque Balloon Fiesta is the largest hot air ballooning event in the world, a celebration of colour and joy. It is a spectacular event for balloon pilots

THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains run almost the length of North America. They start in the North-west but lie only a few hundred miles from the centre in more southern areas. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps they are no less wonderful. There are many roads across the Rockies but the best way to see them is to travel by train. There are many different railroads which pass through the Rockies. There is a train called 'Rocky Mountaineer' but the most famous is probably the 'Canadian Pacific Railroad' which runs from Montreal to Vancouver. Along the route you can see awe-inspiring scenery including lakes, forests, mountains, and waterfalls. There is also a long train called 'Amtrak'. This runs from Chicago to Seattle passing the Rockies near the Canadian border. It is not as fast as the Canadian Pacific but it is cheaper. However if you want the fastest train go to Denver, in Colorado, and get on the Burlington Zephyr. This is a sleek, modern train which leaves at 7am and reaches Chicago by 8pm. In the summer, when the weather is clear and sunny, the Rockies are at their best. It is a very popular holiday time and many holidaymakers go to the Rockies. During the rest of the year, snow and ice make the Rockies very dangerous and it is often difficult to cross them.

Winter Driving Winter is dangerous because it's so difficult to know what is going to happen and accidents take place so easily. Fog can be waiting to meet you over the top of a hill. Ice might be hiding beneath the melting snow waiting to send you off the road. Snow falls and covers all signs, and plow trucks cannot reach them all. But that is nothing compared to the snow, rain, and the salt mixture that the roads are soaked with. The mixture is called snow and ice, or a winter wonderland, or an icy death trap. As I drive down the snowy roads I get angry when I see all the people not being cautious. They drive fast, not paying attention and cause danger for everyone else. People need to think of their own safety and the safety of others. It is important to know what the road conditions are and what kind of weather is ahead. In winter driving, it's critical to maintain a safe speed and adequate following distance between vehicles. 90% of all winter driving accidents occur within 10 miles of home on days when roads are clear of snow and ice. And 90% of those accidents occur when the driver was going too fast. One of the most common reasons for an accident is a driver not seeing the road or another vehicle in time. Many car headlights are not designed to work well in snow and ice. The glare from snow makes it hard to see other vehicles on the road. There should be no distractions in the car. 26,000 people die every year due to car accidents. 2/3 of those accidents could have been prevented if people would slow down and maintain proper following distances. People should stay in control

THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria in Egypt in 370 A.D. For many centuries she was the only woman scientist to have a place in the history books. Hypatia's father was director of Alexandria University and he made sure his daughter had the best education available. This was unusual as most women then had few opportunities to study.
Hypatia was well known throughout the Roman Empire as a mathematician, inventor, philosopher and astronomer. Hypatia's major contribution to science was in developing and teaching a way of learning called the "Corpus of Hypatia" - a collection of the best knowledge of the day. This helped to spread Greek philosophy and ideas on geometry.
Hypatia used her skills and education to spread the message of tolerance between people of different beliefs. For this reason, she was particularly hated by a group of Christian zealots who eventually killed her. The murder of Hypatia is still an example of what can happen when science and religious dogma clash.

They are well prepared for feeding under water because they can see very well and they can also feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. These make sharks very dangerous for smaller sea creatures that become their food. This essay looks at some of the things sharks eat and also what other types of danger there are in the sea.

First, sharks eat a variety of food and there are different sharks to feed on different things. Some sharks live near the bottom of the sea or even at the top. The bottom feeders include the bottom sharks, angel sharks, wobbegong sharks, and epaulette sharks, while the top feeders are the lemon sharks, tiger sharks, and white sharks. This shows that sharks have a wide variety of food to eat.

On the other hand, there is another danger that is out there in the sea, even more dangerous than the sharks, which is the Great White. The great white shark is the most dangerous animal to ever swim through the seas and oceans. Its body is covered with scars from the fights that it has had with other sharks or with seals or whales. These scars make it look more like a monster and frighten most people who swim in the oceans. These animals are not dangerous to humans but if you happen to swim in the sea where they swim you will need to get out quickly.

No Title The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six" says Margaret Porter a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret who lives in London prefers to take pupils at three and four although she has made lots of exceptions for keen five-year-olds. She teaches children at home and in music schools around the UK and also visits schools for concerts, workshops and talks.

Margaret, who has spent 20 years as a professional violinist and nine as a teacher, says that a young child is easily able to handle the small size of a violin and make friends with their instrument.

She adds: "The reason they are so receptive to learning at this age is because of their incredible brain development. We all know that children at that age pick up language very quickly. They also do it very naturally with no formal teaching."

Their innate curiosity also helps. "They have so many questions, and this curiosity helps to teach them very quickly and easily. When they are two they may not be ready, but between three and six is ideal. After this age their natural curiosity can be affected by school work."

Margaret says that the first year of learning is always the most difficult. "Once they have mastered some basic skills, they can progress quite quickly."

She says that if children show a real love for music, it's worth going with it, even if it means sacrificing other activities for a while. But it's important to make sure the child wants to do it. "Don't push a child into playing an instrument. It is a long-term commitment. They need to be really interested in it."

SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time like disease an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames and the Great Fire of London. There are also details of his personal life.

When and Why it was Written

Samuel Pepys's diary, also known as 'The Diary of Samuel Pepys', was written during one of the most turbulent periods of British history. Pepys wrote about his experiences, his ideas, his beliefs, and his fears. The Great Plague, the Great Fire of London, and the Restoration of the British Monarchy are some major events that he recorded in his diary. In a more general sense, the diary offers a unique window into 17th-century British life.

Pepys wrote the diary because he wanted to record the events that were happening around him. He also wanted to preserve his memories. Like many of his contemporaries, he was worried that he would forget important things that happened during his life. By writing about them in his diary, he ensured that he would not forget them.

Moreover, Pepys intended to produce a biography of his own life. He planned to combine it with the rest of the diary, and even wrote some prefaces for it. Unfortunately, he died before he was able to finish the project.

The History of Shoes In the past importance was not given to shoes being comfortable or fashionable. These early foot coverings were probably animal skins which people tied round their ankles during cold weather. We still use leather today but other materials such as silk plastic or cotton are also popular depending on what is in fashion. In the 18th and 19th century, heeled and padded shoes were in fashion among wealthy people, to keep themselves from sinking into the muddy streets of the large cities.

During this time, fashionable shoes were very uncomfortable. Most people wore flat, laced leather shoes. Shoes were also made for practicality. Shoe designs varied in style. The heel was originally created to help ease walking up hills and across sand. In England in the 1800s shoes often had wooden soles. This trend started in the Regency period and continued into the Victorian era. The most famous example is Queen Victoria herself who was renowned for her love of shoes and had many pairs of ornate, colourful shoes.

Shoes became a fashion item with the rise of couture fashion in the late 19th century. Designers started using shoes to show their design skills. Christian Dior introduced ankle strap shoes and Christian Louboutin made coloured and red-soled shoes fashionable. Modern shoe styles have been heavily influenced by designers and celebrities, who use their choice of footwear to make an impact. Shoes are now made from a wide range of materials, including cloth, wood, glass and metal.

The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway travelled by train from Darwin in the north of Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses the Australian continent from the warm northern coast through seemingly endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the ‘famous Ghan’ which is perhaps unfortunate since it is known above all for being late. The train left Darwin on time, but the tracks further north were being repaired and it had to switch to a different route. The new route made the Ghan stop 25 times, and it travelled 3,500 kilometres (2,200 miles) in 55 hours and 44 minutes; 15½ hours longer than scheduled. It also travelled 275 hours slowly, which is one reason why the Ghan is never on time. It is a shame, because the Ghan was one of the first of what would become many tourist trains in Australia and it certainly has an atmosphere all of its own. The food is excellent and the staff are professional and friendly. It is simply too bad that the schedule is so unpredictable. (See the end of the blog for more on Mark's journey by train.)

When I was preparing to write my book, Journeys by Train, a number of people suggested that I write about the Ghan train. I decided to decline, because as far as I could see it was simply a train between two cities. However, what makes the Ghan stand out is how difficult it is to get to those cities. The assembly line

One of the most important reasons he was so successful was that he used the assembly line to make cars faster, easier and cheaper to make. The assembly line is a way of making things faster by moving the thing that is being made along a line of people or machines that do one thing over and over again. Ford wanted to use the assembly line to make cars so he could sell them to ordinary people as well as rich people.

The Model T The Model T was the first car to be made with the assembly line. It was a small car that could be driven by anyone and could be used on rough roads. The Model T had the same parts as other cars but it cost only half as much. It was a success all over the world. By 1927 the company had made 15 million Model T cars. But after 1927 Ford stopped making the Model T to make other types of cars.

Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon I left my handbag on the bus. In it were my cheque book address book and my purse which contained about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realised what I had done it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old I was a long way from home and I was quite worried. But a kind lady on the bus, seeing me looking so lost, came up to me and asked if I was all right. I told her about my handbag, and she offered to take me to the Police Station and help me report the loss, even though she was going in the opposite direction. I was really touched by her kindness.

On 21 January a 60 year old man called Michael was in a pub in Llanelli, Wales, and he had a stroke. He was found by fellow drinkers and they called an ambulance which took him to hospital. There he had a second stroke. Michael had never been in hospital before, so he didn't know what to expect. He felt lonely and afraid. But then two policemen, who were also visiting the hospital that day, came into his room. They said hello to him and spoke to him, and made him laugh and feel more at ease. He was so grateful to them for making his stay at the hospital more enjoyable.

So, even though the world has many problems, there are still kind and caring people around us.

Therese Healy

STAMP COLLECTING - IT’S A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW AND GROW Millions of people of all ages enjoy a hobby which is both interesting and fun. And every year more and more people start a stamp collection of their own and discover an interest which can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. They are on letters and packages arriving at your home, and in stores and offices. The question you need to answer is: “What type of collection do I want to build?” That will determine what stamps you pick up, where you look for them, and how much you will pay. A collection of stamps is called a philately and there are many different types: 

1. Classical Stamps: The first step for most stamp collectors. These are the stamps that you see on envelopes, and they usually have pictures or designs of national heroes or events. Collectors are especially interested in stamps issued between 1840 (when the first adhesive stamps were used) and 1940.

2. Postal History: This focuses on the study of stamps and mail from a particular area, such as a city, country, or colony. It includes letters, postcards, postal stationery, covers, and labels.

3. Postal Stationery: This involves items such as postal cards, envelopes, and stationery that is already paid for.

4. Modern Stamps: This involves stamps that have been produced since 1940. This area of collection is very popular because there is always something new to find, and stamp issues are often tied to historical events, famous people, and other subjects.

THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s gold was discovered in what is now the most northern state of the USA Alaska. Many people came to the area hoping to get rich. New towns were built and grew quickly. One such town was called Iditarod which means 'far distant place'. In 1925 a serious diphtheria epidemic broke out in Nome, Alaska. A life-saving serum was in Anchorage but it was a thousand miles (1600 km) away! The quickest way to get it to Nome was by dog sled. A team of 20 mushers and around 150 sled dogs started at 4 am on January 27, 1925. The teams of mushers travelled across rivers and mountains. It was a very difficult and dangerous journey through the Alaskan wilderness. After 5 days 5 hours and 16 minutes they reached Nome at 8 am on February 2, 1925. All of Nome cheered as the serum arrived. 30 years later, in 1953, the first Iditarod sled dog race took place. It started from Anchorage and ended in Nome following the same dangerous trail as the 1925 serum run. Thirteen teams and 65 sled dogs set off in the very first race. Today, the Iditarod is an annual dog sled race held every year in early March over nearly 1,100 miles (1,770 km). A race like no other, it has attracted adventurers and dog sled drivers from around the world.

Many zoos, have breeding programs to increase the number of certain species so that they do not become extinct in the wild.

In addition, many zoos play an important role in educating the public. They teach children and adults about the importance of the natural world and the need to protect it for future generations.

Another function of zoos is to provide a place to carry out important research. For example, a zoo may be studying the behavior of a particular species, how it lives in its natural habitat, what it eats, or how it communicates with others of the same species. Many zoos are also working hard to increase the number of animal species that are kept and how the animals live and survive in captivity.

Water scarcity has been a critical issue in the region for centuries. It is part of the reason why many people continue to have a hard time growing anything besides date palms which are incredibly water efficient. The trees store water in their bulbous dates and when the date is consumed the water is released again into the body.  

In contrast to many crops that need to be irrigated, Date palms require very little water.  

In ancient times many people believed that the palm tree was a gift from God, an answer to their prayers for sustenance in the desert. The fruit was a source of nutrition and the fronds and trunks were used for shelter and clothing.

HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It consists of water and sugars. Bees may travel as far as seventy-five thousand kilometres and visit over two million flowers to produce just half a kilo of honey. The colour and flavour of honey depend on the type of flower visited. It is used as a food sweetener, in cooking and in medicine.

Honey is made by honeybees through a process where they collect nectar from flowers and store it in their honey stomachs, then pass the nectar to the house bees, who dehydrate it and store it in honeycomb, the cells in which they live.

Honey is used in food to sweeten it and also to make some drinks, medicine and other products. Because it never gets spoiled, it can be stored for a long time. In some places in Africa, honey is used instead of water in cooking.

Woman in market selling honey Honey can be produced throughout the year, but the yield varies with seasons. In the early spring, the honeybees do not find enough flowers to collect nectar. But as summer and autumn come, there are enough flowers and the bees collect nectar.

Honey is also used in medicine and in beauty treatments. The Egyptians used honey in their mummification process and the ancient Greeks used it to dress their wounds and to treat eye infections.

Wild Flowers. In summer and autumn, honeybees collect nectar from a variety of wild flowers, including thyme, heather, rosebay, foxglove, clovers and willow herb.

No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection New Writing 3 although I cannot understand why. Surely 500 pages of original writing of this quality for £6.99 is pretty amazing? Fiction - both parts of novels and complete short stories - makes up most of the book. There are some enjoyable pieces by famous writers such as Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain.

New Writing 3: Faber Finds [Faber and Faber, 2004]

I was delighted to see how many young, new authors are starting to make a name for themselves, and how many new authors of ethnic origin are represented. It's not only a reflection of our society in all its diversity, it's also an exciting indication of how our world is changing.

The collection also contains some poetry and creative non-fiction. I'm not a great fan of poetry in general but found the poems in this book to be very accessible and easy to read. There is also a great mixture of voices - from the political rants of Zoe Williams to the quiet wisdom of the anonymous 'Cassandra's Daughter'. Some might find the final short story, by the late David Foster Wallace, rather dense and hard to follow.

I found it a little overpowering in its length and complexity but I admired the depth and clarity of his writing. If you don't like it, it doesn't matter. There are plenty of other things to enjoy in this amazing and wonderful book.

I am sure that I will read many of the authors in the book more than once, and already look forward to the fourth in the series.

Then his eyes wandered over the town to far away where the ships' lights shone. The moon in its first quarter hung over the hill to the west and the stars were clear and bright. Five minutes later Dr Kemp pulled down the window again and returned to his writing desk.

A lot can happen in five minutes. I found myself wondering what might have been happening on the ships out there.

It's like a tease, really, as we know so little about those ships. They might be full of sailors sleeping off a hard day's work, or prisoners sentenced to work on those ships indefinitely, or they might even be ships full of ghosts that appear one night for no good reason. There are endless possibilities. And that's before you even consider what happens on shore.

This excerpt is just a snippet, but it's enough to set a scene and leave the imagination free to wander. That's one of the reasons I love reading. I'll spend a long time with my head in a book because it can transport me to different places and times, let me see the world through different eyes, and offer countless possibilities.

What do you like about reading? Do you love the endless possibilities that stories offer, or do you prefer the familiar comfort of what you already know? Do you enjoy escaping into a world of your own making, or do you like to know where your characters are headed from the very beginning?

We are being bombarded with advertisements all the time and a lot of them are targeted at young people. Smaller children apart from spending their own pocket money can also influence what their parents buy so many TV ads are created with kids in mind. For example adverts for drinks feature cartoon animals.

One of the main problems young people have with advertisements is that they are not always honest and the things that are shown in them can look very different from reality. For instance, many cosmetic advertisements seem to show models who have perfect skin but actually their skin is often airbrushed to look better. Many people don't understand this.

Another issue is that a lot of the advertisements are targeted at young people and they often make the products seem better than they really are. In addition, they sometimes encourage unhealthy practices or habits, like drinking fizzy drinks or eating too much fast food. They also pressure people into buying products they don't really need just because they are advertised by celebrities or idols.

On the other hand, people who make the ads are very creative and sometimes they are very helpful. Interview Tips First impressions are often lasting ones. Studies show that people form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress our eye contact our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk our volume and tone of voice as well as our our actual words. People may even form impressions from just our clothes and the way we smell! So the way we dress and groom are important as are the first words we say about ourselves. First impressions aren't always right but they set the tone for the rest of the interview. Preparing for the interview will increase the likelihood of your success.

1. Plan to get to the interview at least 10-15 minutes ahead of the scheduled time. You don't want to be late for the interview.
2. Take a few moments before the interview to take deep breaths and quiet your mind. A short walk in the fresh air or practicing mindfulness or meditation will help calm your nerves.
3. Make eye contact with the interviewer when you first meet. A strong handshake will send a powerful message that you are confident and self-assured.
4. The first words you say will set the tone for the rest of the interview. Begin by saying, "It's nice to meet you." and then quickly share something interesting about yourself. For example: "I enjoyed reading the company's newsletter. I noticed that the company has won several awards for its excellence in customer service."
5. Remember the acronym STAR when describing your experience. S - Situation - share a problem you faced while working with a client. T - Task - describe the work you had to do. A - Action - tell what

Charles Darwin (1809-1882) developed a revolutionary theory of evolution that transformed the way we understand the world and we see ourselves. In On the Origin of Species published in 1859 Darwin described the process of natural selection. The 'fittest' animals or plants - those with the characteristics best suited to their environment - are more likely to survive and reproduce. Gradually, over many generations, these beneficial traits become more common in the population. The theory challenged the established religious belief that humans were specially created by God. Darwin was an English naturalist who became renowned not only for his theory of evolution but also his contributions in the area of plant and animal geography, climate, geology, animal behaviour, marine biology, entomology and psychology.

Favourite places Bruce I don't like landscapes which are completely untamed. It's the human element which is important to me. It's the same when I travel abroad. Lovely villages with old temples attract me not empty deserts. When I was eight I went away to school in England and on Saturdays I would cycle to the village of Lastingham in its lovely valley. In Lastingham, there was a ruined medieval abbey, built by a monk who used to sit there in a hollow tree. I never forgot the sight. So when I went to India for the first time with my family, I was delighted to find the ruins of a monastery on the top of a hill, with another monastery and a holy forest below. It was lovely to walk among the old trees and read inscriptions in the stone. There's a lot of history there, a lot of sadness and a lot of suffering. I could feel it. I would love to visit again and again, and write about it in my diary. But I couldn't stay there forever because I miss my family. I love them a lot. There are many other places in the world which attract me. When my friend suggested that we should go together to China, I was delighted. I was excited to see a landscape which is completely different from the one I saw in India. In China, too, there were ruins, monuments, but the trees and flowers were different. I liked it because there I could see life among ruins and I could get a sense of eternity. I like these special landscapes which are not completely untamed but have traces of mankind on them, even if they are ruins.

IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends as much time as she can at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel Mills teaches and does research into marine geochemistry which means she studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.

Rachel is fascinated by the different layers of water in the sea that have been there for thousands of years. ‘At the base of the Atlantic Ocean is water that hasn’t changed for at least a hundred and fifty years. We have discovered clues to what happened in the past through measuring the isotopic and chemical composition of these deep-water layers.’

Rachel’s research has taken her to the South Atlantic. She spent three months on board the RRS James Clark Ross which is a research ship. ‘Being at sea for three months was an incredible experience. I was in awe of the beauty of the ocean and the wildlife we encountered.’

There is an amazing variety of sea creatures in the ocean such as squids, whales, and dolphins. Rachel and her colleagues also saw sharks. ‘While they are scary-looking creatures, they are quite placid and are no bother as long as you don’t provoke them. I hope I can go on more research trips because I just love the ocean.’

Rachel spends a lot of time under the ocean surface in a submersible – a small submarine. ‘The submersible can take me down to 3,000 metres in the ocean. That’s so deep that the pressure on my body can be as much as a tonne per square centimetre!’

Legally it belonged to the People's Republic of China a part of the colony that was never British. In fact neither Chinese nor British law had effect there. In the eyes of the law it did not exist. 

With a population of about 50,000-55,000 people squeezed into less than a sixth of a square mile, Kowloon Walled City was perhaps the world's most crowded place. The buildings seemed to grow spontaneously. Without plan or permission the structure expanded around an open space filled with garbage, debris and sewage-a place where children played. 

Kowloon Walled City became an iconic symbol of urban blight and a byword for urban sprawl. The Hong Kong government was keen to demolish it and replace it with housing for 30,000 families. In 1993, the 22-acre area was razed to the ground.

It’s true - we’re all getting too big for our boots Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy when he left school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - because Chris though still only fourteen was already almost two metres tall. At fifteen Chris was signed up to the navy, and at sixteen he joined up. But he was soon told by the navy he was too big to serve in the sea. 'The navy had a weight limit,' says Chris, 'but that was not a problem. I was too tall instead. It wasn’t just the height either. My feet were too big. Even my clothes were too big. The trousers kept falling down so I had to hold them up with my knees. I was told I couldn’t serve in the navy, but they kept me on as an extra pair of hands on board. I was a very useful person on a boat.' It wasn't just size that gave Chris the edge though. 'I was also the perfect cook. Everyone would want to be my mate because they knew they’d get good food. So I made a lot of friends, and had a lot of respect from the people on board.' What did Chris want to be when he was younger? 'I wanted to be a flagpole,' says Chris. 'But as I got taller, it seemed the people around me were getting smaller, and they said I had a future in acting.' And Chris, who is now six foot eleven inches tall, is happy with the way things turned out. 'Yes,' he says. 'I think I was right.’

In April 1919 the British rulers in India decided to put down protests in the city of Amritsar. As people gathered in the public garden during the festival of Vaisakhi a British general ordered his soldiers to block the exits and shoot into the crowd. As well as thousands of injuries there were hundreds of deaths. The massacre was the worst moment of repression during the British colonial period.

The event, known as the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, led to many protests within the British Empire and throughout the world against British rule in India. In Britain itself there was outrage as the massacre was revealed by Indian newspapers as well as those in the UK. Demonstrators gathered outside the India Office demanding justice.

In response to these criticisms the British attempted to suppress the information reaching their home audience, using postal and telegraph censorship to curtail the spread of news about the event. Despite these measures, newspapers in the UK and around the world published reports and pictures of the massacre. British Prime Minister David Lloyd George called for an inquiry into the events of the massacre, but the colonial authorities in India responded with a whitewash report.

The event has been an ongoing source of tension between Britain and India to this day, particularly the refusal of the British government at the time to conduct an impartial inquiry into the events.

In 2013, the British Prime Minister David Cameron apologized for the massacre and for the British role in India’s partition, while India’s Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said the British had to answer for their actions.

SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS How to cope with a child who shows outstanding musical ability? It's not always clear how best to develop and encourage their gift. Many parents may even fail to recognise and respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour.

The solution may be to seek help and support from a Specialist Music School. These schools are specifically tailored to meet the special needs and abilities of those with a high level of musical aptitude and, in many cases, a similar ability to learn other complex skills as well.

These schools have talented and experienced teachers who can nurture your child's potential, who will recognise their skills and develop them further.

These schools provide a range of facilities and equipment that are crucial to assist a developing musician and help them excel, with everything from music practice studios and concert halls to music therapy facilities.

The focus is on the child’s potential, and schools aim to create the best possible learning environment that stimulates growth and creativity. With small classes and lots of individual attention, every child is encouraged to discover their strengths and make the most of their talent.

The only British woman scientist to win the Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country says Georgina Ferry but she is little known For the past four years I have been subjecting friends and acquaintances to the Dorothy Hodgkin test. It's very simple: when asked what I am working on I tell them I am writing the first biography of Dorothy Hodgkin. They nod knowingly and ask: 'Who's that, then?' I try to explain that she was a British scientist who won the Nobel prize in 1964 for her work on protein structures, and that her portrait was on the new £20 note. Invariably, I find they are totally blank. This seems odd, because Hodgkin, who was born in 1910 and died in 1994, was the first and only British woman to have won the Nobel prize in sciences and is therefore a landmark figure in the history of British science. She was also the only British scientist, male or female, to have won the Nobel prize twice. But Hodgkin's absence from the public's consciousness is the result of a broader problem: women's scientific achievements are far less known than their male counterparts' achievements. Under Sarah's Spell Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist whose paintings are designed to deceive the eye by creating the illusion of reality. Here she is interviewed by Joanna Watt There cannot he many artists who l10 not sign their work unless they are asked to. Sarah Janson a trompe-l'oeil artist is one. She is a British artist who works primarily with oil and acrylic on canvas to create paintings which look remarkably like photographs. Her work has featured in major art fairs and she is a Royal Institute of Painters in Water Colours member. Sarah says she became interested in trompe-l'oeil as she loved the idea of being able to make the viewer question what they are looking at. "The paintings seem to exist in their own world - you can see them in a photograph, as if they're a painting in a painting," she says.

"I like the idea of deceiving the eye and causing a slight moment of confusion, where the viewer thinks that the painting is a photograph. Once I have established this, I try to find the most subtle ways of showing that it is actually a painting."

Although trompe-l'oeil has been an art form for centuries, Janson likes to introduce a contemporary edge to her work, and she often incorporates digital manipulation techniques, making use of layering, blending and manipulating brush strokes. For this reason, her paintings are not only difficult to photograph but also to reproduce on the canvas. "One of the biggest challenges I face when I'm creating the painting is figuring out the colour palette," Janson admits. "I have to decide on the overall palette and then find a way to manipulate that colour palette

I HAD a most peculiar period of my life when I didn’t have any summers. When the rest of the country was basking in the sun, we were out in the field, my father and I, planting the 55,000 trees which turned the derelict Wicken Fen from an environment of weeds into one of beauty. It took me a long while to find the motivation to re-engage with nature on a personal level, but that experience with the trees and the sense of renewal we gave to the Wicken Fen project remain a turning point in my life. In many ways, they still are. I had always been interested in ecology, even as a small boy. But as a student at Cambridge in the early 1960s, it did seem a little wayward and unfashionable to be obsessed with trees and nature conservation at a time when the rest of the world was in the midst of an industrial revolution. The only place I found solace was when we were out in the field, the sun beating down and the earth, so alive and fertile in its abundance. Publisher A Reviews are absolutely key for publishers - the first part of the newspaper we turn to. Positive reviews can sell books, whereas negative ones can often damage a book's sales - especially if it is a first-time writer. A bad review, on the other hand, can stop some people in their tracks. Reviewers can, however, be an essential part of the launch strategy, and a publisher may decide to delay reviews until a few months after a book is published. Publisher B The value of reviews for individual books depends on the profile of the book - its genre, subject matter, reputation of author and publicity machine. The success of a book in terms of sales and reviews can have a feedback loop effect - good reviews sell books, which leads to more reviews, which sell more books, etc. Reviews can sometimes define the success of a book, or be the cause of it's failure, or lead to word of mouth selling (or not selling). Publisher C Reviewers can and do play a significant part in promoting a book, sometimes by writing an extremely positive review that is quoted on the book cover, sometimes in the way that a negative review can increase sales for a popular author. But there is no rule of thumb and the effect of reviews is unpredictable. Publisher D Reviews matter greatly when the book is by a known or important author. WEATHERVANE MAKER THE MAKING of weathervanes is an ancient skill going back to early Egyptian times. Today the craft is still very much alive in the workshop that Graham Smith has set up. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham’s designs are individually created and tailored to the specific requirements of his customers. In his own words, “I am constantly inspired by new designs and ideas.” The traditional weathervane is a finely balanced copper sphere that turns gently in the wind. The wind direction is shown by the position of the arrow. Graham’s weathervanes are designed to be robust and functional as well as decorative and aesthetically pleasing. Each of his weathervanes is handcrafted from a sheet of copper using a simple pair of tools - a pair of pliers and a blow torch. The basic form is created by following a line that is drawn around the copper sheet. The line forms the shape of the finished weathervane, which in turn follows the basic form. When the line is complete, Graham uses the pliers and blow torch to work the shape up. As the shape forms, the copper is heated until it starts to soften. It is then bent into place. This is a labour-intensive and time-consuming method. There is no machinery or assembly lines involved in the making of his weathervanes. The process begins with a design being drawn on paper. This design is then transferred onto the copper sheet. From there, it is a laborious process of following the drawn line by shaping the copper. Once the shape is complete, it is left to cool. This denial of the industry's youthful target audience was a crucial point, because it made tobacco executives deny the connection between advertising and smoking by children.

"The industry was caught in the act of doing something that could not be justified, so it had to deny that it had done anything at all. The defense, in essence, amounted to this: 'The companies were not targeting children. We are innocent. We don't know how kids came to know our brands.' If the industry was not targeting teenagers, why did they spend millions of dollars advertising to them?

Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal characterised by the sharp spines which cover its body. The hedgehogs are found in many different parts of the world none is native to either America or Australia. All species of hedgehog share the ability to roll into a tight ball when attacked so that their spines point outwards. Hedgehogs can be found in Europe and Asia, and in the southwestern United States and Mexico.

The word "hedgehog" is derived from the Old English hecghehogu, hoccehogu, meaning "hedge pig." The Latin term for "hedgehog" is erinaceus, and the name is sometimes applied to any of the 15 species of hedgehogs.

There are about 17 different species of hedgehogs in the world, ranging in size from about 5 to 30 inches long, and some hedgehogs even reach weights as heavy as 15 pounds. Some hedgehogs weigh as little as 8 ounces.

Hedgehogs are insectivores and mostly eat insects, but some will also eat small vertebrates such as frogs, mice, and birds. They will even eat berries and nuts. They are nocturnal creatures which means they are awake mostly during the night and sleep during the day.

Hedgehogs have a short, strong, snout and ears which are only slightly visible. Their eyes are small and dark and their vision is not as good as their sense of smell. They have sharp, curved claws which they use for digging burrows and foraging for food.

Blacksmiths THROUGHOUT the ages iron has exerted a powerful pull on the human imagination and the men who work it have often been regarded as much more than skilled craftsmen. Before the Industrial Revolution blacksmiths enjoyed the same status as doctors and astrologers because they were the sole providers of weapons armour and farming tools. This volume brings together 350 years of ironworking in one splendid collection of over 100 drawings, photographs, diagrams and documents. All the items are drawn from the remarkable Collection of Ironwork at the V&A Museum, which is unique in its scope and quality. It contains some of the earliest examples of iron casting as well as a vast array of work from the Middle Ages through to the modern day. Among the highlights are a 16th-century gun carriage that once served the might of Spain a remarkable manganese-steel mace from the 18th-century Indian subcontinent and an ironwork masterpiece of the 17th century. This superbly produced book will appeal to historians students of metallurgy and all those with an interest in ironwork.

Anjana Ahuja reports. Astronomer Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is best known for the comet that bears his name. But the man who predicted the comet's return every 75 or so years also left a lesser-known legacy. In 1700 he travelled up the east coast of Greenland to explore the variations in Earth's magnetic field that might have hindered navigators of the time. His journey had a tragic end. Halley's ship got stuck in pack ice and all but one of his crew died. His story has fascinated British geologist Dr Toby Clark for many years. This summer Clark and his team of researchers embarked on their own expedition to Greenland in order to unravel the mysteries of magnetic field variations along Halley's route. "Sir Edmund Halley's expedition had been very much a voyage into the unknown," says Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey in Edinburgh. "He didn't know whether he would be eaten by polar bears or trapped in ice for the rest of his life." The expedition was also perilous because magnetic field variations could spell disaster for the sailors. Magnetic compasses, which point to the Earth's magnetic North Pole, not true north, are affected by variations in the magnetic field. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world comprising over six hundred works. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. One of the most prominent pieces in the collection is a cast of the Discovery of the Hiding Achilles group of statues, from the Roman Baths in Bath, England. Other highlights of the collection include a cast of the Chatsworth Apollo and the Chatsworth Diana, as well as a large number of Roman sarcophagi, including that of the late Emperor Tiberius. There are also many beautiful fountain sculptures in the museum. The Museum of Classical Archaeology is located in South Kensington on Exhibition Road, but can be seen from the Street from the outside. Admission is free.

B. The Museum of Paleontology and Comparative Anatomy of the University of London The Museum of Paleontology and Comparative Anatomy of the University of London is a world class institution. Its collections of fossils, skeletons, and natural history specimens are world renowned for their significance in the field of evolutionary biology. The museum houses an impressive collection of fossils, including a complete skeleton of Iguanodon from the Isle of Wight, a cast of the skeleton of the largest dinosaur ever found, the Argentinosaurus, and a large collection of bird fossils. The museum also holds a large collection of natural history specimens, including skeletons of marine mammals, large African animals, and many birds.

You're also too nice if you always try to make up excuses for people when they mistreat you.

POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER the peacocks that roam free within Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire expose their magnificent trains to the critical and often disdainful gaze of the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day: how in this competitive world where nature as Tennyson said - is red in tooth and claw could birds have evolved such an obvious extravagance?

Darwin knew that the peacock's train is not merely a gift but a form of natural artistry - and an expensive one at that, as the bird's energy is sapped by a display that he himself described as a "costly badge of nobility".

What could nature have possibly achieved by such wasteful flamboyance? This "elaborate ornamentation" - with its 140 eye-spots, each one representing a tiny brain in the peahen's eye - is the product of nature's most enduring game of seduction and intrigue. As it turns out, the answer is hidden in the wings of an unlikely insect: a moth.

At night, with only the faintest moonlight, female Luna moths fly through the darkness to find a mate and reproduce. As it happens, the male Luna moth has evolved an extraordinary trick that allows him to recognise the female and avoid the many competing male moths.

In the darkness, the male Luna moth flutters its delicate, translucent wings, revealing not only a unique and unmistakable "signature" pattern of bright eye-spots, but also the glowing green light that the insect uses to find the opposite sex. NATURAL TALENTS In the mere seven million years since we humans separated from chimpanzees we haven’t had time to develop any differences: genetically we’re still more than 98 per cent identical to chimps. On this grand evolutionary scale whatever it is that separates humans from animals is a very recent development. This means that if there’s a way for animals to do something really well, it would be safe to assume that we humans should be able to do it just as well. For example, every animal has the natural talent to move fast, jump high and catch things – humans have no greater innate ability than any other animal on the planet when it comes to these physical feats. Similarly, every human is a natural artist. We may not necessarily be as good as professional artists, but if we give it a try we should be able to produce some work that is artistic.

If everyone had the same natural ability for certain tasks, then in a world without competition there would be no reason for anyone to excel in them. However, there is a competition in life and that is why only some individuals will choose to try to maximise their skills, while others won’t bother to try. The fact that all of us were born with the same physical capabilities also explains why so many people spend their whole lives trying to convince themselves that genetics alone were responsible for an inability to excel in sport or the arts – and that they could have done better if only they were blessed with an extraordinary physical constitution or had more natural talent. This is an attempt to avoid accepting personal responsibility.

Chewing gum culture It’s fashionable classless and Americans chew 12 million sticks of it a day. Discover how an ancient custom became big business. Chewing gum contains fewer than ten calories per stick but it is classified as a food and must therefore conform to the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration.

Chewing gum has been around for thousands of years, but the modern form that we’re familiar with now only came into existence in the late 19th century. The process was developed by Thomas Adams and it used chewable chicle from the sapodilla tree, which has been used as chewing gum by the indigenous people of Central America for centuries.

In 1871, Adams imported the first shipment of chicle from Mexico. By the early 1900s, Adams and a number of other entrepreneurs, like William Wrigley Jr., had established the mass production of chewing gum. Wrigley’s first gum, called Wrigley’s Juicy Fruit, introduced an aluminum foil wrapper and was one of the first gums to be marketed in packs rather than individual sticks.

The gum culture has since exploded. In the 1950s, Bazooka Bubblegum introduced comic books as an item in every pack and in 1997, Bazooka added a baseball card and trading advice to the packs. Bubblegum remained popular amongst children into the 1970s when bubblegum cards started to become more prominent. The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition. It’s a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others. But transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Unless that is it is newspapers’ ‘transition’ to the online world an uncertain and highly uncomfortable process – because frankly it may not be a process at all.

There is a danger that the old medium is dying before the new has truly emerged. The end is not yet in sight, not by a long chalk, but the writing is there, for all to see, on the digital wall. As of mid-May the online audience for the Telegraph, the Guardian and the Times had soared far above the numbers served by their paper editions. The Mail Online has already eclipsed them.

Even the most enthusiastic defenders of print are having their doubts. Some argue that the web is no more than a fad: a fad, perhaps, but an unstoppable one. I keep meeting editors and newspaper executives for whom the web is the new passion and print their former mistress.

Print is not in decline. The market for quality print, however, is: it is shrinking while digital demand is soaring. The Telegraph is, without question, an internet success story. Its new owner, David and Frederick Barclay, have spent vast amounts to make it a success and the gamble is paying off. Its online audience is now about 60% of its total readership.

Ancient Chinese medicine in the West? Acupuncture is two thousand years old. It comes from the traditional Chinese system of medicine that includes herbalism massage diet manipulation and exercise. It is used to treat many different conditions but acupuncture’s role in treating pain has received most attention by doctors in the West. The basis of acupuncture lies in the idea that our bodies have meridian lines or channels that run through the skin and down to the muscles. When our bodies are healthy these lines flow freely. When we are sick or injured blockages or stagnations occur along these lines. A person who is feeling pain is thought to have blockages in his or her meridian lines. By stimulating certain points on the skin the acupuncturist attempts to open up the blockages and restore the natural flow of energy called qi. The Western understanding of acupuncture is that it somehow stimulates the body to produce pain killing chemicals like endorphins and enkephalins. It is also believed that acupuncture affects other systems in the body including the central nervous system. Acupuncture treatment usually involves inserting one or more small needles into the skin. There are over three hundred different points on the body known as acupuncture points. The points chosen will depend on the individual’s symptoms. The needles used are very thin and only stay in the skin for a very short time. Some people find the needling process very relaxing and even pleasurable others describe it as being painful especially if the acupuncturist is treating very tense muscles. When the needles are inserted the patient will feel a mild tingling sensation and some people even describe it as an electric shock. It is normal for a patient

Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems certain therefore that sleep has a vital function. However what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are far from being in agreement about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. I would like to take a look at some of the leading theories.

1. Brain Tonic
First up is the 'brain tonic' theory. Sleep, says the theory, acts as a way of resting the brain. Just as the muscles in our bodies need rest, so too does the brain. It is essentially a recovery time, a period where the brain can 'recover' and 'reset'. The synaptic connections in the brain which are crucial to its functioning, the theory suggests, are strengthened and reinforced during sleep. In other words, sleep is crucial for mental health, just like physical health. Just as muscles atrophy through lack of use, so too the synapses could deteriorate without the benefit of sleep. According to this theory then, sleep is essential for mental health.

2. Memory Consolidation
A second theory suggests that sleep is important because it aids memory. It is during sleep that memories are consolidated, or fixed, in the brain. This happens particularly during a form of sleep called 'slow-wave sleep', or 'deep sleep'. This is a phase of sleep that happens early on in the sleep cycle. During this time, the brain is thought to be reviewing all the information it has received during the day. In effect, it is organizing the information and filing it away, creating order out of the 'noise' of the day. According to this theory

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and the right chairs are the key to a happy healthy workforce according to a new survey. We went to four contrasting offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. On our expert panel were a building health consultant; an ergonomist who studies people’s working conditions; and an occupational psychologist. A few surprising revelations.

Alastair Hanton runs Hantons, a design firm, which specialises in creating offices that are healthy and sustainable for their occupants. The firm uses the Feng Shui design and philosophy in creating healthy workspaces.

According to Hanton, office space should be a balance between two extremes. At one end is the “white-collar” type of office space with air conditioning, heating, and high technology; and at the other end is the “blue-collar” type of space with natural ventilation, natural light, and no technology. The goal is a balanced mix of both that is both technologically equipped and green and healthy.

The building health consultant said that, first and foremost, a healthy office space should have adequate ventilation. He explained that ventilation is a major factor in a workplace, but the most common mistakes made are not providing enough air, poor air filtration, and not using ventilation systems properly. He also emphasised the need for good lighting, not only in terms of brightness, but also in terms of colour and temperature. Natural light was recommended as much as possible.

The ergonomist said that the design of the chair in the office plays a very important role in the health of the workers. An ergonomically designed chair should be comfortable, and should support the lower back, especially the lumbar region.

I’m not the sort of person who makes resolutions on New Year’s Eve. Not because I think them ineffectual, although I’m sure they often are, but because I’m invariably in bed by midnight nursing a cold or a hangover.

However, resolutions do seem to work for some people and we shouldn’t make fun of them just because our own lives are as shambolic as the aftermath of a particularly chaotic cocktail party.

New Year resolutions, like diet fads and detox programmes, are a symptom of the fact that we humans are not very good at taking care of ourselves. We don’t need them if we eat the right food, exercise a bit, and take care not to drown in booze or tobacco smoke.

Writing by hand and on screen Dr Johnson maintained that ‘what is written without effort is in general read without pleasure’. The converse is that good writing comes hard. Looking back though my handwritten school essays I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over. But, at the time, they were all I could do.

I did try to teach a dog some tricks. He only had a few in his old age and his memory wasn’t as good as it was in his prime. He had a few tricks left in his old age and he seemed to remember them better in a new home.

I will try to write and write until I have found some meaning in my writing. Some people get bored with writing and don’t want to put the effort into it but it is important to do so. Writing can be a lot of fun and it can also be a way to find out what you are thinking and feeling.

As I have written a lot in my life, I have found that some of the things I have written have been good, but most of it has been bad. That’s because writing is hard work and it takes a lot of effort to make it worthwhile. If you don’t put the effort in, you won’t get anything out of it.

If you want to write, you have to write a lot. The more you write, the better you become at it. So I try to write a lot, even when I have writer’s block, and it helps me to overcome it. I also try to edit my writing as I go along, so that I don’t have to do it later. This is a good habit to get into.

His face is used to advertise products with intellectual connotations from computers to encyclopaedias. Yet the image has little to do with the man himself. Einstein is best known for his theory of relativity, and the equation E=mc2 which has become the symbol of nuclear physics. He did not, however, invent the atom bomb.

Einstein was born in Ulm, Germany, on March 14, 1879. His father Hermann, was an engineer and his mother Pauline, was a housewife. He had one sister, Maja, who died young. As a child, he was not particularly good at school and had trouble concentrating. He had no interest in sport but showed an early talent for music and played the violin and piano.

He eventually joined the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich, where he studied mathematics and physics. In 1905, he became an assistant at the Patent Office in Bern and published a number of papers, including one that proposed a method of splitting the atom. Telescopic equipment was limited and there were few books on practical astronomy. Today the range of off-the-shelf telescopes and equipment covers almost everything one could need. However, although there are hundreds of charts and atlases available, far fewer of them are available in cartographic form than before. There are very many books and magazines on astronomy, and many of these are concerned with amateur astronomy. The basic needs of an amateur astronomer are: A telescope or binoculars. There are different types and sizes of telescope. Binoculars have the great advantage that they require far less maintenance. They are also a good way of getting started, especially if one is uncertain of one’s commitment. Binoculars are also a great help in locating objects when a telescope is being set up, and are valuable for use during daylight. They are invaluable for finding the Sun during solar eclipses, when it may be too dark to read the setting circles of a telescope. In addition, as stated above, they are essential equipment for an eclipse expedition.

The most common telescopes are:
• Refractors (lenses)
• Reflectors (mirrors)
• Catadioptrics (combination lenses and mirrors)

Art In modern times - more and more over the course of the last two hundred years - we have come to speak as though every artist had to rebel against the art of his contemporaries. Art is praised in terms of being unique revolutionary shocking even. We feel good about admiring the artist whose work no one appreciated a hundred years ago.

Modern times have, then, created an interesting situation: the demand for the artist whose work is truly original, yet the desire to imitate the great art of the past - and, most of all, to believe that it is possible to do so.

This contradiction is more than just the typical human weakness of thinking we can achieve what the great master have done and do better.

The great masters - and they are few - have created an art tradition that is not only a powerful force in human consciousness, but also an absolute necessity in our spiritual life. They have built a structure upon which artists today must build. We are still dependent on what they have given to us. It is important to understand that the tradition which our great masters have founded was their gift to us; if we imitate them, we can only be followers. Yet, at the same time, we must go beyond them, not imitate, but be in dialogue with their work.

The fact that we have come to view any significant advancement in art as being a radical shift away from tradition does not mean that the tradition itself is static and unyielding. It is, in fact, a living thing, flexible, constantly evolving, and changing shape in the hands of its practitioners, the artists.

Fashion Fashion is often seen as a modern phenomenon entirely dependent upon nineteenth- and twentieth-century capitalism for its development. Most historians of fashion are at pains to point out though that fashion at least in the sense of style and design has a very long history. They often take the rise of the market and mercantile trade in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries as their starting point. By the sixteenth century European artisans and entrepreneurs had established well-organized international trade in textiles. By this time the word fashion was used to describe the prevailing styles of cloth. The trade was dominated by merchants from Flanders and Italy. These merchants and the artists and artisans who worked for them helped to spread the new styles. The Flemish town of Bruges in particular became a centre for the trade in fashionable textiles. For the first time, as far as is known, there was conscious copying and imitation of specific styles. At the same time some styles and garments became associated with the upper class and some with the lower. In this way clothing came to be associated with social status. For much of European history before this, status had been determined by inheritance or acquisition of land or other material assets rather than by the wealth, success or fashionableness of its inhabitants.

Fashion in Renaissance Italy

In Renaissance Italy, the wealth and prestige of certain families led them to seek distinction by means other than the mere display of possessions. One was the cultivation of an aesthetic awareness, the ability to appreciate or even create beauty. In the sixteenth century this could be achieved in part by dressing in the latest style and by having in one's household talented artists or craftsmen able to create beautiful objects.

Metals It may have been a wish for self-adornment that aroused the interest of Stone Age people in metals. Sitting by the side of a river waiting for a fish to come within a spears throw or just idling away a moment one of our early ancestors might have happened upon a shiny yellow pebble and plucked it off the river bed. It turned out to be gold.
Apart from a few chance discoveries, man’s first knowledge of metals came from the observation of how the copper and tin ores had changed in the natural process of smelting. A group of men who had been roasting copper ore in a hearth noticed that the air around had turned blue and smelled of copper.
The use of metals developed slowly and steadily through a process of trial and error. Early man knew only two metals- copper and gold, copper being the more accessible.
Gold was used mostly as an object of adornment. Gold jewellery from the early stages of its usage have been excavated from the ancient civilizations of Egypt, Mesopotamia, and the Indus valley.

Copper also served as the basis for many other metals to be developed later. By about 4000 BC, man had discovered that by heating copper ore and removing the impurities, a better copper could be obtained. This copper was then alloyed with other metals, mainly tin to produce the first bronze.
Bronze was a revolutionary discovery. It was stronger, harder and much sharper edged than copper or stone and was thus used for making weapons and tools.

Heritage The true meaning and significance of heritage is that it gives people and communities a genuine sense of connection with the past. Obviously we feel connected to our personal heritage usually we know who and what our grandparents were and we will have heard stories about how they lived.

We share and treasure these stories and also our grandparent’s physical inheritance – their possessions, photographs, furniture and decorative artifacts.

But we don’t only have a connection with our immediate family heritage, we also have a connection with the local community, regional, national or sometimes even international heritage.

It could be from our ancestors’ lives and work during the industrial revolution, the Victorian age, or even earlier, or the way our parents and grandparents celebrated holidays and significant life events. We inherit the landscape, the views, the way the town has developed, the architecture and the buildings that are still standing today.

Some people are drawn to heritage in order to explore their identity and a sense of belonging. Others are fascinated by the history and want to learn about the events that have shaped the lives of those who lived before. There are many people who are passionate about preserving the heritage of a particular place because they feel that it gives a sense of authenticity.

Heritage also gives a sense of continuity and roots. It is important for children and young people to understand how the past has shaped the present and that it will also shape the future.

For all of these reasons heritage is significant as it provides a connection with the past, a sense of identity and belonging, a sense of continuity and an understanding of how the past has shaped the present.

Observing Lions In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal.

The reality is very different: lions tend to hunt alone or in small groups and are more likely to get their heads taken off by rival males than to succeed in the kill. The lion’s image as social animals is also reinforced by their behaviour at kills. After a successful hunt they do something that bears do not. Rather than consuming the carcase on the spot, they cover it with grass and go back for their share later. They also share their food with their pride mates and cubs. And while a male lion may be at the head of the pride, the females do most of the actual hunting.

Agricultural Origins Lions, known to the Ancient Egyptians as Mafdet, were considered by ancient people to be of the most sacred significance and were one of the first animals that ancient humans began to tame. It is believed that lions may have been the first animals in general to be tamed by the ancestors of modern humans.

It has been proposed that these domesticated lions were used for many purposes, including for hunting as well as in religious ceremonies. This is based on the observation that the domestication of other big cats, such as the tiger and cougar, followed a similar timeline and has been proposed as having similar purposes.

0ral History The growing trend for historians to rely on oral evidence is not without its problems. It is naive to suppose that someone’s testimony represents a pure distillation of past experience for in an interview each party is affected by the other. In addition, oral evidence is not subject to the same checks and balances as written documents. Yet there is something special in the human element of history, and in allowing the past to come alive through the voices and experiences of those who witnessed it. For this reason, the use of oral history is a valuable source for historians, although it requires meticulous methods of investigation and interpretation. 292 The Importance of Interpretation 12. In the last chapter it was pointed out that the way in which oral history is recorded can greatly affect its reception. Interpretation also plays a crucial role. Even if the content of the oral evidence is accurate, the way in which it is presented will influence the reader’s understanding. A number of devices and techniques can be used to assist with this process. 12.1.1 A Narrative Approach It is generally more effective to present the testimony in the form of a story rather than simply a collection of facts and opinions. By creating a narrative, the reader can better follow the development of an individual’s life or experiences, and the context in which events took place. In addition, a narrative approach helps to illustrate the influence of particular social and historical conditions on the actions and decisions of the individuals concerned. 12.1.2 Analyses and Interpretation As with other forms of historical evidence, interpretation is essential to enable the reader to make sense of oral testimony. Unfortunately for him, his movements had not gone unnoticed.

AESTHETICS By one of the ironic perversities that often attend the course of affairs the existence of the works of art upon which formation of aesthetic theory depends has become an obstruction to theory about them. For one reason: these works are products that exist externally and physically. But aesthetic theory cannot be formulated about them as physical things. This is not because aesthetic judgments cannot apply to things external and physical, but rather because there is, at present, a vast range of things which do not have to be either internally or externally 'real' to be aesthetically valuable and which indeed often do not have the slightest resemblance to the conventional 'art.' In addition, aesthetic theorists are constantly being confronted with objects that are ambiguous as to their status (works of a very particular kind of 'pop art' for example). We have also to take account of the fact that art objects now have a history, an individual, and a social, history, and that their aesthetic values do not exist in a simple and straightforward way in the objects themselves, but are the effects and expressions of the history of the objects. To begin to develop an aesthetic theory able to accommodate these things, one has to begin with a definition of art that is as open as possible. There are, no doubt, many more questions which can be raised as well, but these are a few which have occurred to me. We must ask what is the meaning of the term 'art' or 'artwork' and whether it has a meaning at all. Art has an 'open' history. Can we identify a single essential element of artistic creation? But what usually results is something that looks like a video version of a museum guide book, and which has as much excitement as a lecture on the history of the alphabet.

For a long time the BBC had a flagship arts magazine show called A Brush With Fame which had a title that perfectly caught the snobbery that it so obviously embodied. The show started off promisingly with Jonathon Meades, a writer who makes no secret of his disdain for TV, as presenter. But for some reason the producers couldn't resist the temptation to turn a show about art into a show about 'celebrities'. It's not that the two things have to be mutually exclusive, and occasionally A Brush With Fame came up with a good pairing of a famous person with a particular painting, but it also frequently degenerated into a celebrity chat show where the 'artist' was asked about their latest film/book/TV programme.

The Actor’s Craft Derision and contempt are sprayed at actors from time to time. Much of this disdain is fuelled by the actors themselves when they’re compelled by their film/theatre companies to talk about their craft (and themselves) in interviews. These verbal encounters, which are meant to generate curiosity and sympathy in the audience, are often marked by a cynical self-awareness that turns into a circus of self-congratulation and posturing. In their eagerness to establish their bona fides, actors sometimes overdo things, and the public, wary and resistant to such performances, turns away even more. I, for one, am never more inclined to see an actor’s work than when he or she is the most self-effacing. It’s as though the shimmer of artifice disappears in the shadow of the humble.

There are several reasons why actors should beware of the temptations of self-promotion.

1. Lack of Sincerity: People who work in the arts are often required to wear their heart on their sleeve, so to speak. To achieve this level of openness, a certain degree of vulnerability must be embraced. The moment one feigns this vulnerability to gain sympathy, the authenticity of the whole endeavour becomes suspect. Actors must strive to make their work transparent and meaningful, and this demands honesty about the process.
