Theodore Zeldin looks at how our working life could change.

Are you as respected and appreciated as you deserve?

Success in a career is no longer enough. Every profession is complaining that it is not properly valued or understood and even among individuals who have won eminence there is often bitterness behind the fame. The whole concept of the profession, with its traditional image of expertise and status, is being destabilized by the erosion of authority.

Yet at the same time, a new source of self-respect is appearing: the ability to build relationships. Our work involves increasing levels of cooperation; our leisure pursuits bring us into contact with people whose company we can value for its own sake. A relationship-builder must be as skilled in the ways of the heart as a professional is in the techniques of his specialization.

Relationships are the basis of all human achievements. They are how we do things together that we cannot do alone. At first, this was limited to face-to-face contacts. Then came the telephone and the letter, followed by the telegraph, fax, and e-mail. Language You and I belong to a species with a remarkable ability we can shape events in each others brains with exquisite precision. Language is so tightly woven into human experience that it is scarcely possible to imagine life without it. Chances are that if you find two or more people together anywhere on earth they will soon be exchanging words. There are of course exceptions, but the power of language to help us connect and make sense of the world is undeniable. The power of language can be understood in two ways, the transformative power of language and the shaping power of language. The transformative power of language is the ability to change the way a person feels, thinks or behaves in a dramatic way. By using words we are able to inspire, influence, persuade, encourage, comfort, soothe, excite, challenge, motivate and instruct. The power of transformative language lies in the way we use words to generate emotions, to encourage others to feel and act as we wish.

Transformative language has been used to great effect by politicians, preachers and psychologists throughout history, but it isn’t just these professionals who use transformative language in their everyday lives. Everyone has the ability to use transformative language and the effects of this can be seen all around us. Transformative language is particularly powerful when used in the service of a noble or worthy cause. It can, however, be misused as well. When used to manipulate or control, it can be destructive and damaging. Transformative language can also have a profound effect on our perception of the world and our ability to achieve success.

Kinetic Art Rejoice — the well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder. And not thankfully by some huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media extravaganza but by a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. A new exhibition traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the twentieth century.

Momentum: 20th Century Kinetic Art opens up to the public at the Hayward, South Bank Centre, from 10 March to 9 June.

Kinetic, or motion, art has had several definitions — the most prevalent of these is ‘art which is concerned with movement’. This was the most ambitious of all forms of art in the twentieth century — and perhaps the most elusive. This was not an easy world to capture. In the words of the exhibition’s curator, Andrew Wilson, Kinetic art’s ‘proponents hoped for a synthesis of the visual, the tactile, the audio and the temporal’.

The exhibition is the first to celebrate the art of movement and includes more than 100 works by 30 artists. Kinetic works range from the 1920s — which saw an outcry in the London Evening Standard from John Betjeman against the introduction of moving images in the Victoria and Albert Museum — through to the 1980s — which saw a proliferation of video and digital installations.

The history of kinetic art in Britain is largely unknown, as is that in the rest of the world, with the exception of the USA. It is an art form which has been largely overlooked until now.

Paul Simon Rock and roll in the 1950s was primarily a youth cult but its lasting importance lay in the seismic impact it had on the middle class and the middle-aged. It also paved the way for the next generation of rock idols who listened to it awestruck and aware that this strange unsettling sound would somehow irrevocably be linked with their destinies. There is one name above all others, one figure that looms over the entire pantheon of rock’s heroes and antiheroes, its fallen and its victors. Paul Simon first gained prominence as half of the duo Simon & Garfunkel, whose soundtrack to the 1967 film, The Graduate, gave them an almost instant national profile. Together, they became two-thirds of Simon & Garfunkel (Arthur Garfunkel being the other third) and as a team they created some of the most beautiful, harmonically complex, melodious and intelligent folk-rock ever recorded. It’s a sound that has stood the test of time, one that still fills concert halls from Sydney to New York, London to Los Angeles.

Born in Queens, New York, in 1941, Simon grew up in a music-rich environment – jazz at home and the doo-wop and R&B from the streets – which helped shape his ear. At school, he played drums and sax, and from an early age he was deeply engaged with music history. As a teenager he bought Elvis Presley’s first single and, more importantly, Chuck Berry’s ‘Roll Over Beethoven’, which he played again and again on his guitar.

POETRY RECITALS At any given time in history the literary scene will seem confused to those who are living through it and it is the selectivity of posterity that makes the pattern and orders of eminence appear clearly defined to the retrospective view. We see the rise of a poet, of a school of thought, as clearly defined in his moment and in his milieu. But the very success of a poet, or the emergence of a literary movement, is, in fact, not an event of one time or place, but of a complex of times and places, each of which has a different validity, in that the historical time of the poet is not that of his work, nor is the place of the poet that of his work. As long as the historical time of the poet and his work is conceived, the idea of a living poetry will remain vague and uncertain and it will seem to be just so much that the poet lived at a certain time and wrote poetry then, or a school of thought and other poets and writings of the same time and place, in which these works are only one item among others, all equal and of equal validity. It is only when we understand that the historical time of the poet and his work is not the same, and that the historical time of the poem or the work of the poet lies elsewhere, that the significance of poetry can be defined and the distinction of works can be understood.

To say that poetry is not merely a product of a certain time and place and that it rises and falls in the human mind by reason of influences of which man is often unconscious, is not an attempt to make poetry a universal art which transcends the limits of race

CRYING Charles Darwin thought that the human tendency to cry had no obvious evolving purpose. He was almost certainly wrong. More recently scientists have pointed to its social significance with psychiatrist John Bowlby highlighting the role of crying in developing the attachment between mother and child. Many believe that tears at least during childhood are mainly an expression of helplessness. Now further research on the science of tears, which include an enzymatic analysis of the biological components of tears, has suggested that they might be even more important in maintaining our well-being. According to research at the University of California, a chemical analysis of tears shows that these liquid drops contain pain killers and stress reducing hormones. In a paper published in ACS’s Journal of Proteome Research, an elite group of scientists, led by Raul Donazar from the Department of Pharmacology at the University of California, analyzed several enzymes found in tears and found that they include a variety of proteins and peptides that function as analgesics (pain killers), anti-inflammatories and anti-anxiety, anti-depression agents. The scientists further analyzed a protein called RNAase7 in tears to confirm its antiviral properties. A protein found in tears could offer a new way to fight viruses. RNAase7 is already known to have antiviral activity, but the results show that levels of this protein in tears are considerably higher than previously thought. RNAase7 is found in the ‘mucous membranes’ of the respiratory tract and the ‘lachrymal glands’ (tear glands), and it is believed that during times of intense weeping the concentration of this enzyme increases, providing a natural defense against viruses. Blogging: Confessing to the world Some time ago a website highlighted the risks of public check-ins – online announcements of your where-abouts. The site’s point was blunt: you may think you are just telling the world ‘Hey I’m at this place’ – but you are also advertising your out-and-about-ness to all kinds of people everywhere – not all of them people you might like to bump into. But the author went a step further. He argued that by regularly ‘checking in’ at different places, a pattern is built up. You are painting a mural of your life. A mural of your life that anyone can wander past and examine. And, like an amateur painter, if you are not careful, you are leaving traces of your personal life on the canvas that you didn’t mean to. It’s an interesting point. A good blogger has to confess: his or her writing isn’t just about the facts. It’s a story about him or herself. My blogs are about me, about what I believe and what I think. I can’t write from behind a cloak of invisibility – without declaring anything about me. I can’t keep myself out of my writings. Even in what I think is a simple analysis of theology or a brief look at a historical event, my own beliefs and presuppositions shape and interpret these subjects. There is always something of me, always a bit of my own life woven into every post – even the ones that don’t seem to say anything directly about me. So that means I have to be prepared to admit that. I have to be okay with my readers knowing who I am. I have to be okay with my life being on show. That means being honest – even on the blog. How to Write Poetry Telling people how to write poetry is a bit like frolicking through a minefield: spontaneity is the order of the day but one false step and a dozen certainties will blow up in your face. I will, therefore, make some general suggestions on this matter, without being responsible for any ensuing explosions.

Firstly, let's consider the basic elements of poetry: sound and sense.

Poetry can, by definition, be seen as sound. Rhythm and cadence are what make poetry special compared to prose. They work with or against the meaning of words and can alter their meaning by the way they are pronounced, by the pauses, and by the pacing of the language. This aspect of poetry comes down to two elements: line and stanza.

Line is the way a poem is broken up into sections. There is no strict rule on how many lines a poem must contain but it is a good idea to aim for the right length. The line length should be suitable for the message it is trying to convey. For example, it would be unsuitable to write "To be or not to be" in one long line because it would lose its meaning as soon as it went beyond one's breath. It would not be as melodic or musical as the original line, split into two:

To be, or not to be.

The two sisters kept Lily’s driving a secret from Chen for some time. She would drive around the allotments and the railway line and gasworks shooting the tiny hump-backed bridge with all four wheels in the air and a tremendous bump (Lily's only misjudgement) before completing the journey by the gasworks in an odour of sulphur and brimstone.

She loved it.

It was another month before they decided to tell him. “We just couldn’t bear to see her being so happy and not telling him. It was a decision that was difficult but we hoped it would be okay in the long run.”

Chen was thrilled. He just couldn’t believe she had been doing it for a month without telling him. He insisted on accompanying her on the next trip.

So how does this experience connect with your life right now?

You might be feeling as if you are stuck in a life you don’t particularly enjoy, yet are not sure how to make changes. You may have a small secret you have been keeping from a loved one, like Lily did from Chen. Perhaps the fear of change or the uncertainty of what will happen if you tell is holding you back. What Lily and her sisters did was a kind of controlled experiment. They knew that Chen would be supportive and wouldn’t make her stop. If he had been angry or critical, they could have reverted to the old way of things.

What if you were to tell someone close to you what you are feeling right now, even if it is just one person you trust? How might that change the way you feel? What if you took baby steps in the direction of the new life you want, just like Lily drove slowly and carefully along the roads she had never driven before?

Every Picture Tells a Story Adapting novels for film almost always involves a process of reduction condensation and deletion. This can be very frustrating for the writer but also illuminating. Working on a script I was struck by how much of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene in the novel I could dispense with while still getting across the same point. The challenge of course is to come up with something that will do the trick on a single screen or page rather than several pages. The great thing is that cinema is all about pictures as much as dialogue. Every scene in a film has to work both visually and emotionally. Otherwise, the audience will lose interest. This is why most novelists are not good filmmakers. Their books may contain wonderful descriptions of a character or a mood or an event, but they usually don’t have a visual or emotional point. This is also why adaptations can work so well. The best adaptations take advantage of the strengths of film and eliminate the weaknesses of the novel. This is why the original novel is often sacrificed in the interest of a more effective and satisfying film. (Read more at the link...) ——————— For full article: Huffington Post

The world has never experienced a rise in temperatures as fast as 0.5C per decade. Changes in temperature and rainfall may affect food production, leading to food shortages in developing countries. Many people will be forced to move, and millions could be at risk of losing their homes. So how can we tackle this global problem? Maps The purpose of a map is to express graphically the relations of points and features on the earth’s surface to each other. These are determined by distance and direction.

There are many types of maps that use different ways to express these relations and different purposes. For instance, topographic maps show topographical details with relief shown by contour lines or shaded areas, while road maps express the relations of streets and towns or cities in such a way that a person can find his way from one location to another.

The two-dimensional nature of a map, however, requires that a certain degree of simplification be applied. This simplification is necessary, because if all details of every map were expressed in their actual relative sizes and shapes, the resulting map would be extremely difficult to read.

On the other hand, the simplifications may create misunderstandings. Therefore, it is important that the user of a map is aware of these simplifications. In other words, he should know “how to read a map”.

The most important map distortions and the way to interpret them are the following.

Photography When a photographer takes a photograph he or she makes a selection of visual information that is determined by his or her technical and aesthetic skills personal views and experience together with a set of social and cultural norms. A photograph is a two-dimensional surface and therefore can only record this visual information as a two-dimensional projection. By selecting this specific information, the photographer is able to use the camera as a tool with which he or she can communicate with the audience and through which he or she can project their personal vision of the world. This is the nature of photography. The selection of visual information is what gives a photograph its meaning.

The photographer selects information on a number of different levels. On a technical level, he or she is required to consider the principles of photography, such as the appropriate focus, shutter speed and aperture setting for the situation. These decisions are based on the photographer's training and personal experience. On an aesthetic level, the photographer makes choices about what is pictorially interesting in the frame of the camera, what is the most effective way to compose the picture, and how to organize the picture in terms of light, color, shape and texture. These decisions are based on the photographer's artistic judgment and creativity. On a social and cultural level, the photographer makes choices based on the cultural norms and social practices that determine what is acceptable and what is not.

MUSIC AND THEATRE Up until quite recently I would have said that opera is first and foremost theatre. Not any more. After a brief spell working at u national opera house I learned that opera is in fact only secondly theatre. The music comes first. That’s as it should be of course. It’s an amazing experience to see great opera singers on stage, but if they can’t sing then it’s not really opera. That might sound like a very simplistic opinion but it’s actually a very important point. Opera is, at its most basic, about the human voice – and not just any voice, but a voice trained and disciplined and skilled to the highest level to produce sounds that would be impossible for an ordinary person to replicate. So the singers may be called actors, they may be called performers, they may even be called artists but when it comes down to it, the primary consideration is that they must have an amazing voice.

In the world of theatre there are a lot of very fine actors, in fact there are some genuinely wonderful performers, but you rarely find a theatre performer who is also an opera singer, and never an opera singer who is just a theatre performer. That’s because opera requires a very different skill-set. There is a lot of similarity in terms of the basic physical and psychological challenges of performing in front of an audience, and there is also a lot of similarity in terms of how stories are told. But the way in which they are told and the level of skill required is very different.

So in the theatre, in all its many forms and genres, what does matter most? Is it the music? It never used to be, not for me anyway

Writing Reviews Frank Kermode examines the craft of review-writing from a practitioner’s point of view. Most reviews are written and circulated under conditions which ensure that they have a very short active life. That is, the work they refer to may be overtaken by the next day’s news, by other books, or simply by more thoughtful or intelligent reviews. The reviewer therefore cannot hope to make a lasting contribution to the world of ideas or literature. On the other hand, reviews are very important indeed – they do make a difference – so it is a kind of service that has to be provided without thinking too much about lasting impact. The writer must be ready for the reader to be more knowledgeable than he is. He must not attempt to sound like an expert, or rather, the truer expert he is, the less he can get away with appearing in that guise. He must appear to be a fellow reader, one who is ready to take as much pleasure in the reading as he hopes the reader will take in the book under review. Reviewers are, in other way than one, like clowns, and should be given the same freedom as clowns have to be uninhibited and to do what they do as well as they can. Reviews should not be too long, or too short, or too serious, or too frivolous, or too earnest, or too lazy; the reviewer who tries to meet all the possible qualifications for a good review will get into trouble. He may not be able to get the job done properly if he tries to live up to all the images of what a review should be.
